questions.text: A patient has mental retardation, seizures, thrombotic state, amino acid metabolism disorder, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis. Which vitamin must be supplemented to the patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin B6

 

The clinical presentation, including mental retardation, seizures, a thrombotic state, osteoporosis, and ectopia lentis, is characteristic of homocystinuria.

 

Homocystinuria is a genetic disorder caused by a deficiency of cystathionine beta-synthase (CBS), an enzyme involved in methionine metabolism. This deficiency leads to an accumulation of homocysteine, which can cause a wide range of symptoms, including neurodevelopmental issues, skeletal abnormalities, and vascular complications.

 

Vitamin B6 (pyridoxine) is crucial in the management of homocystinuria, as it is a cofactor for CBS. Supplementation with vitamin B6 can enhance the activity of the residual enzyme, helping to reduce homocysteine levels in responsive patients, thus mitigating the symptoms and reducing the risk of complications such as thrombosis.

 

Note –

 

The causes of ectopia lentis include several conditions, such as Marfan's syndrome, homocystinuria, Weill-Marchesani syndrome, and Ehlers-Danlos syndrome. These are important to remember when identifying the underlying cause of lens dislocation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin B12: While vitamin B12 is also involved in homocysteine metabolism, deficiencies in B12 are not directly related to the presentation seen in homocystinuria. B12 supplementation is more relevant to other conditions such as pernicious anemia or when correcting elevated homocysteine due to B12 deficiency, but it is not the primary treatment for homocystinuria.

 

Option C. Thiamine: Thiamine (vitamin B1) is not involved in the metabolic pathway of homocysteine. It plays a role in carbohydrate metabolism and is associated with conditions like Wernicke-Korsakoff syndrome and beriberi but not with homocystinuria.

 

Option D. Vitamin B2: Riboflavin (vitamin B2) is not directly related to the symptoms of homocystinuria or the management of this disorder. It is mainly involved in energy production and the metabolism of fats, drugs, and steroids.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Homocystinuria is characterized by ectopia lentis, thrombotic state, mental retardation, and seizures, among other features. Vitamin B6 supplementation is essential in managing this condition by aiding the function of the deficient enzyme cystathionine beta-synthase.

questions.text: All of the following are contraceptive methods used post-coitus except? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Danazol

 

Explanation:

 

  • Post coitus contraception means emergency contraception
  • Danazol is an androgen similar to testosterone and is used in endometriosis and fibrocystic breast disease

 

Other Options:

 

Option B CuT200: CUT200 is an intrauterine contraceptive device which can be used in emergency contraception (up to 120 h/ 5 days post coitus)

 

Option C. RU486: RU486 is Mifepristone. This is an anti-progesterone and can be used for emergency contraception)

 

Option D. Combined high dose estrogen-progestin pills: Combined high dose OCPs – used as Yuzpe’s regime, is a method of post-coital/ emergency contraception 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The following can be used as emergency contraceptives:

 

 

Ref: Page no 630, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6th edition

questions.text: The third ventricle is the cavity of which part of the brain? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Answer: D. Diencephalon

 

The third ventricle is the cavity of the diencephalon, which is part of the forebrain (prosencephalon). The diencephalon consists of thalamus, hypothalamus, epithalamus, metathalamus, and subthalamus. The third ventricle is a narrow cavity that lies between the two halves of the thalamus. It communicates with the lateral ventricles through the interventricular foramina of Monro, and posteriorly it continues as the cerebral aqueduct which passes through the midbrain.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Telencephalon - The telencephalon (cerebral hemispheres) contains the lateral ventricles, not the third ventricle. The lateral ventricles are C-shaped cavities within each cerebral hemisphere.

 

Option B. Mesencephalon - The mesencephalon (midbrain) contains the cerebral aqueduct (aqueduct of Sylvius), not the third ventricle. The cerebral aqueduct connects the third ventricle to the fourth ventricle.

 

Option C. Rhombencephalon - The rhombencephalon (hindbrain) contains the fourth ventricle, not the third ventricle. The fourth ventricle is the cavity of the pons, medulla oblongata and cerebellum.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

The third ventricle is specifically the cavity of the diencephalon, situated between the two thalami, and forms part of the ventricular system connecting the lateral ventricles to the fourth ventricle via the cerebral aqueduct.

questions.text: A young woman wants to take the post-coital pill. Which one should be given? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) LNG

 

The post-coital pill, also known as emergency contraception, is used to prevent pregnancy after unprotected intercourse. The preferred choice for emergency contraception, particularly in many countries including India, is Levonorgestrel (LNG).

 

LNG (Levonorgestrel): Available under brand names such as the "easy pill," it contains 1.5 mg of levonorgestrel. This should be taken within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse to effectively prevent pregnancy. It is a single-dose regimen that is well-tolerated and has fewer side effects compared to other methods.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Norethisterone: This is not used for emergency contraception. It is primarily used in other hormonal treatments, such as for menstrual disorders.

 

Option C. Estrogen: Estrogen alone is not used for emergency contraception due to the risk of side effects and its lower efficacy compared to levonorgestrel.

 

Option D. Estrogen + Progesterone (Yuzpe regimen): Although this method can be used for emergency contraception, it is not preferred due to the higher incidence of side effects like nausea and vomiting. This method involves taking a high dose of estrogen and progesterone and repeating it after 12 hours, which is less convenient and less well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The preferred emergency contraceptive pill is Levonorgestrel (LNG), to be taken as a single dose within 72 hours of unprotected intercourse.

questions.text: A 19-year-old patient presents with generalized edema (anasarca). Laboratory tests reveal proteinuria of 4.5 g/day, hypoalbuminemia, and hyperlipidemia. What is the recommended treatment for this condition? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Steroids

 

Explanation:

 

This patient has nephrotic syndrome, characterized by:

 

  • Proteinuria >3.5 g/day
  • Hypoalbuminemia
  • Generalized edema (anasarca)
  • Hyperlipidemia

 

In young adults and children, one of the most common causes is Minimal Change Disease (MCD), which is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

 

First-line therapy:

 

  • High-dose steroids (prednisone 1 mg/kg/day) for 4–8 weeks
  • 80-90% remission rate

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. IV albumin: Provides temporary relief but does not treat the underlying disease

 

Option B. Cyclophosphamide: Reserved for steroid-resistant or frequently relapsing nephrotic syndrome

 

Option D. Steroids and cyclophosphamide: Combination therapy is not needed initially. Can be used for immune mediated disorders like lupus nehritis as a part of induction therapy. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nephrotic syndrome in children (and some times in young adults) is most commonly due to Minimal Change Disease and is highly responsive to corticosteroids.

choices.text: Thayer Martin agar
Wilson Blair agar

questions.text: A patient presented with pus discharge from the urethra and dysuria. He had a history of unprotected sexual intercourse. The best culture media for the following organism is: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Thayer Martin agar

 

The patient’s symptoms of urethral discharge, dysuria, and a history of unprotected sexual intercourse suggest an infection with Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a common cause of sexually transmitted infections. Neisseria gonorrhoeae is a fastidious bacterium requiring enriched media for growth. Thayer Martin agar is a selective medium specifically designed to isolate Neisseria gonorrhoeae. It contains nutrients that support the growth of Neisseria species and antibiotics (vancomycin, colistin, nystatin, and trimethoprim) to inhibit the growth of contaminating organisms, making it the best medium for culturing this organism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Blood agar: Although blood agar is a general-purpose nutrient medium that can support the growth of a wide range of bacteria, it is not selective for Neisseria gonorrhoeae and does not contain the necessary inhibitors to prevent the growth of other organisms.

 

Option B. MacConkey agar: This agar is selective for Gram-negative enteric bacteria and is typically used for isolating lactose-fermenting bacteria like Escherichia coli. It is not suitable for the growth of Neisseria gonorrhoeae, which does not thrive on this medium.

 

Option D. Wilson Blair agar: This medium is used for isolating Salmonella typhi and is not relevant to Neisseria gonorrhoeae, as it does not provide the specific growth conditions required for this organism.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Thayer Martin agar is the selective medium of choice for isolating Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a bacterium associated with sexually transmitted infections presenting as urethral discharge and dysuria.

questions.text: A patient with suicidal tendency ingested some substance. He presents with tachycardia, dilated pupil, and hypertension. Identify the drug. (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

 

The patient's symptoms—tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension—are indicative of a sympathomimetic toxidrome, which is most commonly caused by stimulants like cocaine. Cocaine is a potent sympathomimetic agent that stimulates the central nervous system, leading to increased heart rate (tachycardia), elevated blood pressure (hypertension), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These clinical signs are classic for cocaine toxicity, especially in a setting involving substance use with suicidal intent.

 

Cocaine blocks the reuptake of norepinephrine, dopamine, and serotonin, leading to an excess of these neurotransmitters in the synaptic cleft, which accounts for the heightened sympathetic activity observed.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Heroin: Heroin is an opioid that typically causes miosis (constricted pupils), bradycardia, and respiratory depression. It does not fit the clinical presentation of dilated pupils, tachycardia, and hypertension, which are opposite of opioid effects.

 

Option C. Morphine: Morphine, like heroin, is an opioid that causes pupil constriction (miosis) rather than dilation. It also leads to decreased heart rate and blood pressure, contrasting the symptoms seen in this patient.

 

Option D. Chlorpheniramine: Chlorpheniramine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties that can cause pupil dilation and mild tachycardia, but it is less likely to cause significant hypertension. Furthermore, chlorpheniramine is not commonly associated with substance abuse for suicidal intent.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine toxicity is characterized by sympathetic overdrive symptoms such as tachycardia, dilated pupils, and hypertension, making it the likely substance in cases of suspected sympathomimetic drug overdose.

questions.text: A 54-year-old male recently underwent Coronary Artery Bypass Grafting (CABG). Within a few days after taking a saphenous vein graft, he complained of pain in the legs, and on examination, he had mild sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot on the side from where the graft was harvested. What is the nerve likely to be injured? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Saphenous nerve

 

The saphenous nerve is a branch of the femoral nerve that provides sensory innervation to the medial aspect of the leg and foot. During coronary artery bypass grafting (CABG), the saphenous vein is often harvested for use as a graft. Due to its close anatomical relationship with the saphenous nerve, the nerve can be inadvertently injured during the vein harvesting process.

 

Injury to the saphenous nerve typically results in sensory disturbances such as pain, numbness, or tingling in the medial aspect of the leg and foot, which matches the patient's presentation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superficial peroneal nerve: The superficial peroneal nerve provides sensory innervation to the lateral aspect of the lower leg and dorsum of the foot. Injury to this nerve would cause sensory loss in these areas, not the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option B. Sural nerve: The sural nerve supplies the lateral aspect of the foot and the posterior lower leg. Injury to the sural nerve would not affect the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Option D. Tibial nerve: The tibial nerve provides motor and sensory innervation to the posterior compartment of the leg and the sole of the foot. Injury to the tibial nerve would affect these areas rather than the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The saphenous nerve, due to its proximity to the saphenous vein, is at risk of injury during saphenous vein harvesting for CABG, leading to sensory loss in the medial aspect of the leg and foot.

questions.text: Below is the air pollution index chart for four consecutive days at the Delhi station. What is the categorization of the air quality index for November 23rd? [NEET PG 2021]
questions.solution:
Ans. (d) Severe

 

Based on the information provided in the query, the air quality index on November 23rd is measured at 407, falling under the severe category.

 

AIR QUALITY INDEX (AQI)

 

A tool used for effective communication of air quality status on a scale that is easily comprehensible. Complex air quality data of various pollutants are compiled to give a single score (index value), nomenclature and color that determines the air pollution of that particular location.

 

Eight pollutants are taken into consideration to calculate the AQI -

 

  1. PM10 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 10 microns or less)
  2. PM2.5 (Airborne particulate matter with a diameter of 2.5 microns or less)
  3. NO2 (Nitrogen dioxide)
  4. SO2 (Sulfur dioxide)
  5. CO (Carbon monoxide)
  6. 03 (Ozone/Trioxygen)
  7. NH3 (Ammonia)
  8. Pb (Lead)

 

AQl categories and the range are as follows:

 

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A 25-year-old woman with primary infertility is found to have bilateral tubal block on HSG. The next best step is? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Laparoscopy with chromotubation

 

Hysterosalpingography (HSG) is often the first test used to evaluate the patency of the fallopian tubes in women experiencing infertility. If the HSG reveals a bilateral tubal block, the next best step is to confirm the findings through laparoscopy with chromotubation. This procedure allows direct visualization of the pelvic organs and the fallopian tubes. Chromotubation involves the injection of a dye through the fallopian tubes to assess their patency directly, which is more accurate than imaging alone. Additionally, if the block is confirmed, there may be an opportunity to address it surgically during the same procedure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. IVF: While IVF is a valid treatment option for tubal factor infertility, it is generally considered after confirming the tubal block with laparoscopy. IVF is often chosen if re-canalization attempts fail or if the patient prefers to bypass surgery.

 

Option C. IUI (Intrauterine Insemination): IUI is not suitable in cases of confirmed bilateral tubal block because it requires at least one patent fallopian tube for sperm to reach the egg.

 

Option D. Letrozole: Letrozole is an ovulation induction agent used in women with ovulatory dysfunction. It is not appropriate for treating tubal block issues and thus is not relevant in this case.

 

Educational Objective:

 

After identifying a bilateral tubal block on HSG in a woman with primary infertility, the next best step is to confirm the diagnosis with laparoscopy and chromotubation before considering other treatments like IVF.

questions.text: An infant with a history of multiple episodes of diarrhea presents with an erythematous, scaly rash, as shown in the image. Which nutritional deficiency is responsible for this condition, and which supplementation should be administered to reverse the clinical features? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Zinc

 

The case describes classic acrodermatitis enteropathica (AE), characterized by:

 

  • Presents around 6 months when weaning from breast milk occurs
  • Diagnostic triad: 
  1. Periorificial and acral dermatitis (erythematous scaly lesions)
  2. Diarrhea
  3. Alopecia
  • Caused by zinc deficiency due to SLC39A4 gene mutation
  • Inheritance: Autosomal recessive
  • Affects zinc absorption in intestine
  • Treatment requires lifelong zinc supplementation

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Vitamin A

 

  • Deficiency causes follicular hyperkeratosis
  • Does not present with periorificial dermatitis
  • No specific association with diarrhea
  • Different pattern of skin manifestations

 

Option C. Vitamin C

 

  • Deficiency causes scurvy
  • Presents with follicular hyperkeratosis and perifollicular hemorrhages
  • Characteristic corkscrew hair changes
  • Gum bleeding is prominent

 

 

Option D. Iron

 

  • Deficiency causes koilonychia (spoon-shaped nails)
  • Associated with angular cheilitis
  • Does not cause periorificial dermatitis
  • No direct association with diarrhea

 


 

Educational Objective: 


Acrodermatitis enteropathica presents with the triad of periorificial dermatitis, diarrhea, and alopecia due to zinc deficiency, requiring lifelong zinc supplementation.

questions.text: In children, which of the following tumors most commonly arises in the epiphysis? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans: A. Chondroblastoma

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity. The epiphyseal region is predominantly affected by chondroblastoma followed by giant cell tumor (which typically occurs after skeletal maturity). Chondroblastoma is often referred to as Codman's tumor and characteristically presents with calcification within the epiphysis. It typically appears as a well-defined lytic lesion surrounded by a zone of sclerosis with areas of calcification giving it a mottled appearance radiographically.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Aneurysmal Bone Cyst (ABC) - This is primarily a metaphyseal lesion that occurs in the 2nd decade of life. ABC is multiloculated, eccentric and expansile in nature, commonly affecting the tibia. On MRI, it shows characteristic "fluid-fluid levels" due to its multiple septae.

 

Option C. Osteosarcoma - Osteosarcoma characteristically affects the metaphysis of long bones, particularly around the knee (lower femur, upper tibia). It rarely crosses the growth plate into the epiphysis and presents with aggressive features like periosteal reaction and Codman's triangle.

 

Option D. Unicameral Bone Cyst - Also known as Simple Bone Cyst (SBC), this lesion occurs in the metaphysis of long bones, most commonly in the proximal humerus. It typically presents in the 1st decade of life with a central, single cavity containing straw-colored fluid.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Chondroblastoma is the most common epiphyseal tumor in children before skeletal maturity, while after skeletal maturity, Giant Cell Tumor becomes the predominant epiphyseal tumor.

questions.text: An adult man in a restaurant suddenly begins choking on his food. He is conscious. The following procedure was performed. Identify the procedure: (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Heimlich’s maneuver

 

The image shows a Heimlich's maneuver

 

First aid for foreign body in the airway -

 

A large bolus of food obstructed above the cords may make the patient totally aphonic, unable to cry for help. He may die of asphyxia unless immediate first aid measures are taken.

 

The first aid measures consist of pounding on the back, turning the patient upside down and following Heimlich maneuver. These measures should not be done if the patient is only partially obstructed, for fear of causing total obstruction.

 

Heimlich maneuver. - Stand behind the person and place your arms around his lower chest and give four abdominal thrusts. The residual air in the lungs may dislodge the foreign body providing some airway.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Back Slaps: Before attempting the Heimlich maneuver, delivering five firm back slaps between the individual's shoulder blades can be tried as this may dislodge the item.

 

Option C. Chest Thrusts: Used instead of abdominal thrusts in cases where the Heimlich might be risky, such as in very obese or pregnant individuals.

 

Option D. Blind Finger Sweeps: Not recommended due to the risk of pushing the object deeper into the throat, potentially worsening the blockage.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Heimlich maneuver is an effective emergency procedure for saving lives in cases of severe choking. It is important for everyone to learn this technique as it can be performed on others or even on oneself in a choking emergency.

 

Ref - Dhingra 7th edition, Page No. 367

questions.text: A patient develops acute confusion and disorientation shortly after undergoing surgical intervention for a malignant tumor. Which of the following medications is typically the first-line treatment for this condition? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Haloperidol

 

The patient is experiencing acute confusion and disorientation following surgery, which suggests the development of delirium. Delirium is a common postoperative complication, especially in older adults or those with significant medical conditions. The first-line treatment for delirium, particularly when it is accompanied by psychotic symptoms or severe agitation, is antipsychotic medication. Haloperidol is a traditional antipsychotic that is commonly used in this situation due to its efficacy in controlling these symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lorazepam: Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine, which is not typically used as a first-line treatment for delirium. It is more appropriate in the treatment of delirium tremens, which is a specific type of delirium associated with alcohol withdrawal. In cases of delirium not related to alcohol withdrawal, lorazepam can actually worsen the confusion.

 

Option C. Olanzapine: Olanzapine is another antipsychotic that can be used to treat delirium, but it is not considered the first-line treatment as Haloperidol is more commonly preferred in acute cases.

 

Option D. Risperidone: Risperidone is also an antipsychotic that can be used in the management of delirium, but similar to Olanzapine, Haloperidol is generally preferred as the first-line option.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Haloperidol is the first-line treatment for delirium, especially when the patient exhibits significant agitation or psychotic symptoms following surgery.

questions.text: Which drug would be most effective in preventing withdrawal symptoms in a patient with a history of alcohol consumption who was admitted to the hospital after a road traffic accident? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Lorazepam

 

Lorazepam is a benzodiazepine commonly used to manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms. Alcohol withdrawal can present with symptoms like anxiety, tremors, seizures, and delirium tremens, which can be life-threatening. Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, work by enhancing the effect of the neurotransmitter GABA, which has a calming effect on the nervous system, thereby reducing the risk of withdrawal symptoms.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Fomepizole: This drug is an alcohol dehydrogenase inhibitor used primarily in the treatment of methanol and ethylene glycol poisoning, not for managing alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option C. Naltrexone: Naltrexone is an opioid receptor antagonist used to reduce cravings and prevent relapse in patients recovering from alcohol or opioid dependence. It is not used to manage acute withdrawal symptoms.

 

Option D. Buspirone: Buspirone is an anxiolytic used for the management of generalized anxiety disorder (GAD). It is not effective for treating alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Benzodiazepines, such as lorazepam, are the drugs of choice to prevent and manage alcohol withdrawal symptoms.

questions.text: Which of the following tissues is most radiosensitive? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Testis

 

Radiosensitivity refers to the susceptibility of tissues or cells to the harmful effects of radiation. The testis, particularly the germ cells within the testis, are highly radiosensitive because they have a high rate of cell division and less differentiation. Gonads, in general, are among the most radiosensitive tissues in the body. This is why testis is the correct answer.

 

Although bone is mentioned, it is not specified whether it refers to bone marrow or bone tissue. Bone marrow is indeed highly radiosensitive, but when only "bone" is mentioned, it generally refers to the harder, more resistant bone tissue rather than the marrow. Hence, in the presence of the option "testis," which is clearly highly radiosensitive, the testis is the more appropriate choice.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Muscle: Muscle tissues are relatively radioresistant because they consist of mature, differentiated cells that do not divide frequently.

 

Option B. Nerve: Nerve cells are also radioresistant due to their low mitotic activity and high differentiation, making them less susceptible to radiation damage.

 

Option C. Bone: As explained, "bone" generally refers to the solid bone tissue, which is not as radiosensitive as bone marrow. The ambiguity in the term "bone" makes it a less clear choice compared to "testis."

 

Educational Objective:

 

The testis is highly radiosensitive due to the high rate of cell division in germ cells, making it more susceptible to radiation compared to other tissues listed.

questions.text: A 28-year-old male patient presents in surgery OPD with midline swelling in the neck. The swelling moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue. What is the likely diagnosis?(NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Thyroglossal cyst

 

  • Pathology – Remnant of thyroglossal duct
  • Most common site – midline à Subhyoid
  • C/F – Presents in 2nd /3rd decade of life as midline neck swelling which moves up on tongue protrusion and on deglutition.
  • Treatment - Sistrunk’s operation
  • Long standing thyroglossal cyst has a risk of papillary carcinoma thyroid

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Branchial cyst: Failure of obliteration of branchial cleft. Cystic swelling (soft)- typically in a teenager. Swelling at upper 1/3rd + middle 1/3rd junction of sternocleidomastoid.

 

 

Option C. Plunging ranula: Presents as Swelling in floor of mouth, Fluctuation present, Brilliant transillumination.

 

 

Option D. Dermoid cyst: Caused when skin and skin structures become trapped during fetal development.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • A midline neck swelling that moves with deglutition and protrusion of the tongue is characteristic of a thyroglossal cyst, which is a remnant of the thyroglossal duct.
  • The treatment is typically surgical removal via the Sistrunk procedure.

choices.text: Years lost due to premature death
Years lost to poor quality of life

questions.text: The years of potential life lost could be attributed to? [NEET PG 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Years lost due to premature death

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL)

 

Definition: YPLL is based on Years of life lost through premature death

 

Importance:

 

  • YPLL occurs before the age to which a dying person could have expected to survive
  • YPLL is a type of mortality indicator

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Years lost to morbidity refers to the time spent living with a disease or disability, which is not directly related to the concept of years of potential life lost.

 

Option C. Years lost to disability is a component of disability-adjusted life years (DALY). DALY Is BEST measure of burden of disease in a defined population and the effectiveness of interventions.

 

DALY = YLL (Years of lost life) + YLD (Years lost to disability)

 

Option D. life would account into QALY (Quality Adjusted Life Years)

 

Educational Objective:  

 

Years of Potential Life Lost (YPLL) is a measure that quantifies the impact of premature death on a population by calculating the number of years not lived by individuals who die before reaching a specified age. It highlights the significance of early mortality and its impact on society.

questions.text: A 3-month-old baby was presented with severe hepatomegaly, jaundice, and cataract in both eyes. The child appeared lethargic and hypotonic. Identify the enzyme involved? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase

 

The condition described in the question is classic galactosemia, which is caused by a deficiency in the enzyme galactose-1-phosphate uridyltransferase. This enzyme is crucial for the proper metabolism of galactose, a sugar found in milk. When this enzyme is deficient, galactose-1-phosphate accumulates in the liver, leading to the symptoms described, including hepatomegaly (enlarged liver), jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia. The accumulation of galactose-1-phosphate depletes inorganic phosphate, which impairs glycogen breakdown and leads to hypoglycemia.

 

In classic galactosemia, the symptoms typically appear within the first few weeks of life, especially when the infant is breastfed (since breast milk contains lactose, which is broken down into glucose and galactose). The presence of cataracts is due to the accumulation of galactitol, a byproduct of galactose metabolism that forms in the lens of the eye.

 

 

Galactose Metabolism

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Galactokinase: Deficiency in galactokinase leads to a milder form of galactosemia, characterized primarily by the formation of cataracts due to galactitol accumulation. However, it does not cause severe symptoms like hepatomegaly, jaundice, or lethargy, making it an incorrect answer.

 

Option C. Hepatic Glucose 6 Phosphatase: Deficiency in this enzyme causes von Gierke disease (Glycogen Storage Disease Type I), which presents with hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but does not cause cataracts. The lack of cataract formation and the specific features of von Gierke disease (such as lactic acidosis, hyperlipidemia) rule out this option.

 

Option D. Fructokinase: Deficiency in fructokinase causes essential fructosuria, which is a benign condition with no symptoms. Hereditary fructose intolerance, caused by aldolase B deficiency, can cause symptoms like hepatomegaly and hypoglycemia but typically presents after the introduction of fructose into the diet, and does not cause cataracts. Thus, fructokinase deficiency is not the correct answer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Classic galactosemia is caused by a deficiency in Gal-1-phosphate uridyl transferase, leading to severe symptoms such as hepatomegaly, jaundice, cataracts, lethargy, and hypotonia, particularly in breastfed infants.

questions.text: Which adult structure is derived from the embryological remnant marked as ‘A’ in the diagram? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Median umbilical ligament

 

Marked structure A is the allantois, which forms the urachus, which in turn gives rise to the median umbilical ligament.

 

The median umbilical ligament represents the remnant of the urachus (also known as the median umbilical fold). The urachus is a tubular structure that connects the fetal bladder to the umbilical cord and allows for the drainage of urine produced by the fetal kidneys into the amniotic fluid.

 

After birth, the urachus becomes non-functional and fibroses to form the median umbilical ligament. It extends from the apex of the bladder to the umbilicus within the median umbilical fold.

 

The given image shows an embryo at the end of the third week.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Medial umbilical ligament: These are the remnants of the occluded parts of the umbilical arteries. In fetal life, the umbilical arteries arise from the internal iliac arteries and pass to the umbilical cord, carrying deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta.

 

  • In the adult, they persist as the medial umbilical ligaments, which are paired fibrous bands on the inner surface of the anterior abdominal wall, running from the bladder to the umbilicus.

 

Option C. Meckel's diverticulum: Meckel's diverticulum arises from the incomplete obliteration of the vitelline duct (or omphalomesenteric duct), which connects the yolk sac to the midgut lumen during embryonic development. It usually disappears by the 7th week of embryonic life.

 

  • If a portion of the vitelline duct remains, it can manifest as a Meckel's diverticulum. It's found in approximately 2% of the population and is often described by the "rule of 2s" - 2 inches long, 2 feet from the ileocecal valve, 2% of the population, and can present with two types of epithelia (gastric and pancreatic).

 

Option D. Ligamentum teres (Round ligament of the liver):

 

  • The ligamentum teres represents the obliterated remnant of the left umbilical vein. During fetal development, the left umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta directly to the fetal heart, bypassing the liver through the ductus venosus.
  • After birth, the need for this shunt ceases, and the ductus venosus along with the left umbilical vein close up. The ligamentum teres runs in the free margin of the falciform ligament, connecting the umbilicus to the anterior aspect of the liver.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

 

Among the given conditions, the levels of ACTH and cortisol will be highest in Cushing's disease.

 

Cushing disease occurs when a pituitary adenoma, a noncancerous (benign) tumor on the pea-size pituitary gland, secretes too much adrenocorticotropic hormone (ACTH).

 

Normally, ACTH levels are higher in the early morning but not as high as in Cushing's disease.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Early morning: Incorrect because, although cortisol levels are typically highest in the early morning, they do not reach the levels observed in pathological conditions like Cushing's disease. This diurnal variation is normal, with peak levels upon waking and declining throughout the day.

 

Option B. Normal individuals with dexamethasone administration: Incorrect because dexamethasone is a synthetic steroid that acts similarly to cortisol. In normal individuals, administration of dexamethasone typically suppresses ACTH and cortisol production through negative feedback mechanisms.

 

Option C. Addison's disease: Incorrect because Addison's disease is characterized by adrenal insufficiency, where the adrenal glands produce insufficient cortisol and often underproduce aldosterone. While ACTH levels might be elevated due to lack of feedback inhibition, cortisol levels are low, not high.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: A 56-year-old male recently diagnosed with renal cell carcinoma, with imaging indicating a tumor size less than 4 cm, what would be the most suitable initial treatment approach for this patient's condition among the following options? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Partial nephrectomy

 

For tumors less than 4 cm, the recommended procedure is a partial nephrectomy, also known as nephron-sparing surgery.

 

  • This procedure involves removing the tumor and a small margin of healthy tissue surrounding it while leaving the remainder of the kidney intact. It is the recommended treatment for smaller renal tumors, typically less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a tumors). For the 56-year-old patient with a renal tumor less than 4 cm, partial nephrectomy is the preferred initial treatment approach as it aims to treat the cancer while preserving as much kidney function as possible.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Partial nephrectomy + neoadjuvant chemotherapy: Renal cell carcinoma (RCC) is generally resistant to chemotherapy, making this option less relevant for the patient's situation given the size of the tumor.

 

Option C. Radical nephrectomy: This procedure involves the removal of the entire affected kidney, the adrenal gland above the kidney, surrounding fatty tissue, and sometimes nearby lymph nodes. It is the preferred treatment for larger tumors or those that have started to spread outside the kidney. For a tumor less than 4 cm, and with no indication of it having spread, a radical nephrectomy may be more aggressive than necessary.

 

Option D. Radical nephrectomy + postoperative radiotherapy: Renal cell carcinomas are resistant to radiotherapy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Partial nephrectomy is the recommended initial treatment for renal cell carcinoma tumors less than 4 cm in diameter (Stage T1a), as it aims to remove the tumor while preserving as much kidney function as possible. This approach balances oncological control with the preservation of renal function.

questions.text: How muscle spindle able to detect the length while muscle is contracting? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Nuclear bag fibers

 

Muscle spindles are sensory receptors within the muscle that detect changes in muscle length and the rate of change in length. They consist of intrafusal fibers, which include both nuclear bag fibers and nuclear chain fibers.

 

These fibers are dynamic and are sensitive to the rate of change in muscle length (velocity of stretch). They play a crucial role in detecting muscle length changes during muscle contraction by responding to the speed at which the muscle length is changing.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Nuclear chain fibers: These fibers are more static and respond to the absolute length of the muscle rather than the rate of change. They are not primarily responsible for detecting changes during contraction.

 

Option C. Golgi tendon organ: This sensory receptor is located at the junction of the muscle and tendon. It monitors tension rather than length changes in the muscle. It is more involved in preventing muscle damage due to excessive force.

 

Option D. Other muscle receptor: This option is too vague. The specific receptor responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during contraction is the nuclear bag fiber.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Nuclear bag fibers in the muscle spindle are responsible for detecting the rate of change in muscle length during muscle contraction, making them essential for proprioception and motor control.

questions.text: In the medical management of glaucoma, drugs which decrease the intraocular pressure are indicated. Which of the following drugs decreases intraocular pressure by increasing uveoscleral flow? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Latanoprost

 

  • Latanoprost is a prostaglandin drug used to lower intraocular pressure.
  • It works by increasing uveoscleral outflow.
  • Latanoprost is a prodrug that is activated during its passage through the cornea.
  • It stimulates prostanoid receptors on ciliary muscles, leading to the release of matrix metalloproteinases.
  • Matrix metalloproteinases increase uveoscleral outflow.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Timolol: This is a non-selective beta-blocker that decreases intraocular pressure by reducing aqueous humor production. It does not significantly affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Option C. Pilocarpine: A miotic agent that increases trabecular outflow but does not have a significant effect on uveoscleral outflow. It works by constricting the pupil and contracting the ciliary muscle.

 

Option D. Carbonic anhydrase inhibitors (e.g., acetazolamide, dorzolamide): These drugs decrease intraocular pressure by inhibiting the enzyme carbonic anhydrase, thereby reducing the production of aqueous humor. They do not affect uveoscleral outflow.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Latanoprost, a prostaglandin analogue, lowers intraocular pressure by increasing the uveoscleral outflow of aqueous humor, making it an effective treatment option for glaucoma.

questions.text: A patient presents with an intense headache, repeated vomiting, and neck stiffness. Lumbar puncture yields turbid cerebrospinal fluid (CSF). Microscopic analysis shows 90% polymorphonuclear leukocytes, a CSF glucose of 40 mg/dL (serum glucose: 120 mg/dL), and a protein concentration of 200 mg/dL. What is the most suitable treatment approach for this patient? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Ceftriaxone plus vancomycin

 

Explanation:

 

The clinical presentation and CSF findings strongly suggest bacterial meningitis, characterized by:

 

  • Headache, vomiting, neck stiffness (classic triad)
  • Turbid CSF with neutrophilic pleocytosis (90% PMNs)
  • Low CSF glucose (<50% of serum glucose)
  • Elevated protein (>45 mg/dL)

 

Empirical treatment for adult bacterial meningitis:

 

  • Ceftriaxone – Covers Neisseria meningitidis and most pneumococci
  • Vancomycin – Added to cover resistant Streptococcus pneumoniae

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. HRZE (anti-TB therapy): Used for tuberculous meningitis, which presents with chronic symptoms and lymphocytic pleocytosis

 

Option B. Ceftriaxone + acyclovir: Used for HSV encephalitis, which shows lymphocytic pleocytosis and temporal lobe involvement

 

Option D. Cefotaxime + ampicillin: Used in neonatal, elderly, or immunocompromised patients (for Listeria monocytogenes)

 

Educational Objective:

 

Bacterial meningitis treatment involves empiric ceftriaxone + vancomycin to cover resistant pneumococci and meningococci.
